intro: Cassebeera atropurpurea var. glabella, commonly known as the purple-leafed cassava, is a tropical plant native to Central and South America. It is characterized by its striking purple foliage and large, heart-shaped leaves. The plant belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is known for its latex sap, which contains toxic compounds. It thrives in warm, humid climates and requires well-drained soil for optimal growth. The varietal form glabella is distinguished by its smoother, less pubescent leaves compared to other varieties.
